title: Introduction
text:
Hi, welcome to my CASA0023 Learning Diary. A bit about myself:
I am an engineer by training. Graduated from University of Alberta in 2015 with a B.Sc in Electrical Engineering. Been working in the ITS industry since. I’ve also got a Master of Information Technology from Monash University in 2019. Working as a graduate engineer in Melbourne for a few years and then product/solutions manager in the autonomous driving and smart cities industry.
I am interested in transportation and urban evolution mostly. My career will be focusing on urban mobility and smart transportation from this degree on.
Besides working on transportation challenges, I like to imagine how technology will evolve with us, humanity, into the future. Read and watched quite a few science fictions and learning about random subjects. For example, I was into hand-made Corsi-Rosenthal boxes during 2021 and 2022. I also likes to code. Here is the link to my side projects hosted on github:

title: Week 4 Remote Sensing and Policy Implications
text:
Remote Sensing and Policy Implication
Focusing on Melbourne with Methodology derived from (MacLachlan et al. 2017)
Utilizing(Trinder and Liu 2020) the Sentinel 5P data.









Area of Research
Global Agenda
Methods
Data




Melbourne urban growth, provide forecasting advice for population growth.
UN SDG
Using Remote Sensing Data
Combine the local councils’ plans


Forecast bush fires in areas that may impact the residents.




























MacLachlan, Andrew, Eloise Biggs, Gareth Roberts, and Bryan Boruff. 2017. “Urban Growth Dynamics in Perth, Western Australia: Using Applied Remote Sensing for Sustainable Future Planning.” Land 6 (1): 9.


Trinder, John, and Qingxiang Liu. 2020. “Assessing Environmental Impacts of Urban Growth Using Remote Sensing.” Geo-Spatial Information Science 23 (1): 20–39. https://doi.org/10.1080/10095020.2019.1710438.

title: Week 5 More on Temperature and Group Work Discussion
text:
Temperature and Urban Heat Island
This week’s discussion on the temperature and Urban Heat Island is carried on from last week’s content.

title: Week 5 More on Temperature and Group Work Discussion
text:
Group Assessment Key Points
Here are some key takeaways for group assessment references:

How to perform the feasibility analysis? Approach from the following aspects:

Technical: Can we do it with the tech we have?
Economic: Is it worth the hassle?
Legal: Are we breaking any local or international laws?
Operational: How will the project unravel?
Scheduling: When to do what?

Common global agendas related to remote sensing and urban studies:

UN Sustainable Development Goals
the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030
The New Urban Agenda (NUA)
The Global Green New Deal (GND)

Other keypoints that we agreed upon for this project is to develop the work covered in the pitch into Work-packs, perform SWOT analysis, design automated Data Pipelines, and adding a Gantt Chart.
The topic and scope is also settle with the help of Andy and our PGTAS! (But the brainstorming is utterly a thrill since everyone has contributed novel ideas to develop!)

title: Week 6 Google Earth Engine
text:
This is a very exciting week, GEE is something that interested me before selecting this module. But that was mostly working alongside GIS folk in a project, seeing them making satellite maps with GEE was a curious experience back then.
Here is a video that I used for learning GEE:

title: Week 1 Introduction to Remote Sensing
text:
Overview
For the first week, we are introduced to the concept of remote sensing and how to download data and images collected by satellites and perform basic analysis with SNAP and R.
For this practical, I picked Bristol as its distinct urban and suburb area split. The data is downloaded from EU Copernicus Data Portal and Earth Explorer.

title: Week 1 Introduction to Remote Sensing
text:
Summary and Reflection
Remote sensing is certainly more than what I have previously pictured, an extension version of image processing i.e. a glorified version of Lena.png processing. On the contrary, it consists of a health amount of geophysics, actual physics, and last but not least geography. In short, it is an interdisciplinary realm comprised of decades of studies and applications.

title: Week 3 Corrections
text:
This week we covered the corrections
This is an interesting concept since it is very interesting to explore the concept of this and that.

title: 1  Common Acronyms in Remote Sensing
text:
RS: Remote Sensing
GIS: Geographic Information System
GPS: Global Positioning System
LIDAR: Light Detection and Ranging
NDVI: Normalized Difference Vegetation Index
EVI: Enhanced Vegetation Index
MODIS: Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer
"Landsat": "Land Satellite",     

"AVHRR": "Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer",     

"GOES": "Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite",    

"NOAA": "National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration",     
"EOS": "Earth Observing System",     

"DEM": "Digital Elevation Model",     

"DSM": "Digital Surface Model",     

"DTM": "Digital Terrain Model",     
"VIIRS": "Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite",     

"UAV": "Unmanned Aerial Vehicle",     

"INSAR": "Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar",     

"ASTER": "Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer",     

"TM": "Thematic Mapper",     

"ETM+": "Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus",     "OLI": "Operational Land Imager",     "TIRS": "Thermal Infrared Sensor",     "SWIR": "Shortwave Infrared",     "MWIR": "Mid-Wave Infrared",     "LWIR": "Long-Wave Infrared",     "PAN": "Panchromatic",     "MSI": "Multispectral Imaging",     "HSI": "Hyperspectral Imaging",     "RADAR": "Radio Detection and Ranging",     "GNSS": "Global Navigation Satellite System",     "VHR": "Very High Resolution",     "FOV": "Field of View",     "AOI": "Area of Interest",     "ROI": "Region of Interest",     "GCP": "Ground Control Point",     "RMSE": "Root Mean Square Error",    ,     

"GHz": "Gigahertz",     

"MHz": "Megahertz",
"SNR": "Signal to Noise Ratio",    
"CAD": "Computer-Aided Design",     
"BIM": "Building Information Modeling",     
"WMS": "Web Map Service",    
"WFS": "Web Feature Service",     
"API": "Application Programming Interface",    
"RGB": "Red, Green, Blue",     "IR": "Infrared",     "UV": "Ultraviolet",     "PCA": "Principal Component Analysis",     "SVM": "Support Vector Machine",     "RF": "Random Forest",     "DL": "Deep Learning",     "AI": "Artificial Intelligence",     "ML": "Machine Learning",     "EO": "Earth Observation"
